oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data, though being inorganic compounds containing chlorine

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (oral route) value of 210mg/kg (RTECS (2005)).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the rabbit LD50 (dermal route) value of 1,500mg/kg (RTECS (2005)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in ICSC (J) (2000): "flare and irritation of the eye/skin/respiratory tract." The substance is thus considered to cause skin irritation (though the severity of the effects is not presented) and classified into Category 2 from the viewpoint of safety.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the description in ICSC (J) (2000): "flare and irritation of the eye/skin/respiratory tract." The substance is thus considered to cause eye irritation (though the severity of the effects is not presented) and classified into Category 2A-2B from the viewpoint of safety.

germ_cell_mutagenicity.hazard_statement: May cause an allergic skin reaction
germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Mercury is classified into a "Skin Sensitizing Substance" by the ad hoc committee of the Japanese Society of Occupational Allergy, and "Skin Sensitizing Substance: Group 1"* by the Japan Society for Occupational Health. These classifications, though not specifying mercurous chloride, seem to include mercury compounds. Mercurous chloride, which is a mercury compound, should thus cause skin sensitization. * There is a provision to the effect that "the category refers to the substance concerned and its compounds, but does not identify all substances causing respiratory/skin sensitization.

carcinogenicity.rationale: No data available As for the mutagenicity/genotoxicity, refer to "ID285, Mercury Chloride (II), CAS: 7487-94-7."

toxic_to_reproduction.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category A4 (as metal mercury and inorganic mercury compounds) by ACGIH (2001) and Group 3 (as metal mercury and inorganic mercury compounds) by IARC (1993).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: No data available As for the reproductive toxicity, refer to "ID285, Mercury Chloride (II), CAS: 7487-94-7."

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (kidney) May cause respiratory irritation (respiratory tract irritation)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale:
Based on the human evidence: "decreased urinary output and edema were observed; renal failure was regarded as a contributing factor of death." (CICAD 50 (2003)) and "eye/skin/respiratory irritation" (ICSC(J) (2000)).
Note: According to CICAD 50 (2003), "renal failure, cardiovascular collapse and severe digestive organ damage are considered to be the causes of death following oral exposure to inorganic mercury. Most common findings among these are gastrointestinal tract lesion and renal failure. Exposure to inorganic mercury appears to induce nephrotic syndrome in humans."

aspiration_hazard.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
aspiration_hazard.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (kidney, nervous system, gastrointestinal tract)
aspiration_hazard.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, black feces, decreased urinary output and renal failure; irritability, fretfulness, sleeplessness, weakness, photophobia, muscle twitching, hyperactive or hypoactive tendon reflexes, confusion, irregular arm movements, and impaired gait" (CICAD 50 (2003)), "dementia and irritability; reduced brain weight observed at necropsy; decreased cerebellar neurons; mercury granules in the cytoplasm found at the light microscopic level" (ATSDR (1994)). Since gastrointestinal tract effects were observed in the repeated dose toxicity studies using the dermal route of exposure, it is unlikely that these effects represented a direct toxic effect, so the GI tract was included in the target organ list.

acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 1 from 48 hours LC50=0.002mg/L of the crustacea (Daphnia magna) (AQUIRE, 2003).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since acute toxicity was Category 1, there was bio-accumulation (BCF=1300 (Existing Chemical Safety Inspections Data)) and it was a metallic compound and the underwater action was unknown, it was classified into Category 1.
